Page Title: R. D. Leta Diary 1906 [1906]
Description: The diary of R. D. Leta for 1906. This diary contains notes on Pu R. D. Leta's daily activities, his involvement with the local Church, his personal reflections on the Gospel, and his experiences in the local Government Office. The local Treasury Office appears several times in the diary. Several other well-known figures appear in the text (for example, Bawrhsap, Zosap, R. Dala, Suaka, and so on). This diary is a useful supplement to the administrative history of colonial and missionary institutions in Lushai Hills. The cover page, which reads “RD Diary 1906” in blue, ball-point pen, is missing from the images, although the image 'EAP454_Lalengliani_97' shows a passing shot of it and has been kept as a clarifier, showing when the 1909 diary begins in the image sequence... Bound, hand-written workbook, measuring 180mm x 230mm. Page Title: L.S. Kulla Diary [1933]

Page Title: Paper records of Dr. Zokhuma [1914-1945]
Description: Three of the earliest matriculation certificates available in Lushai Hills (today's Mizoram). All bear the seal of the University of Calcutta. The certificates are of both Dr. Zokhuma and his father, T. Luaia, the son of M. Suaka, legendary chief of Durtlang. Also included is Dr. Zokhuma's parents' marriage certificate, which must be one of the earliest Christian marital documents in Lushai Hills. The ceremony was held at Mission Veng Chapel, Aijal: one of the historic churches of Lushai Hills. Three school certificates, each measuring 299 mm x 201 mm. One marriage certificate, measuring 211 mm x 134 mm. Pi Thanbuangi notes that the children's drawings on the back of the school certificates were originally on separate, thick, drawing-book paper, which Dr. Zokhuma then pasted onto the back of these certificates to lend them rigidity. Well preserved.                                                          View images from this file (7)

Page Title: Pathian Robawm. God's Treasure Chest [undated]
Description: Sermons on and interpretations of the Bible are provided, through the lens of the local Lushai culture. The language structure is noticeably archaic. It reflects a British understanding of the local language, and feels unwieldy to modern readers of Mizo. English idiom is detectable in the language. C. S. Murray (also known as Challiana) was the son of a British officer in South Lushai Hills. He was adopted and raised by Baptist Missionary Society pioneer missionary F. W. Savidge. They authored this book together. One bound book, measuring 190mm x 125mm. Generally good. Binding separating in places. One loose page. Legal: Access is for research purposes only

Page Title: Chhingchhip [1918]
Description: Pu. C. Vanlallawma notes that this is a picture from 1918 of Chhingchhip Kohhran (the church of the village Chhingchhip). This photograph was exhibited at the Mizoram Gospel Centenary Exhibition in 1994. According to Pu Vanlallawma, an early primary school was established in Chhingchhip by 1911. The chief then was Hrangliana Sailo (son of Kawlhauna) who, though sympathetic to the new religion and its followers, did not himself convert to Christianity until just before his death. Pu C. Vanlallawma notes that in 1939, there was a 'rude and harsh' chief, whose rule made it difficult for local Christians. In more recent times, Chhingchhip has seen the growth of strong Catholic presence; the prominent Montford Brothers established a large school in the village in 1978. One photograph, measuring 158 mm x 87 mm. Very poor condition. Page Title: Set on a Hill: the Record of Fifty Years in the Lushai Country [1944]
Description: This book came out of the author's 1928 visit to Lushai Hills, where she was asked to compile a book outlining a history of the previous decades' work. The book is thus an important record of the early days of Christianization in Lushai Hills (today's Mizoram), and contains valuable information on the geography and people of Lushai Hills, the introduction of Christianity to the region, and the contemporary challenges facing the Mizo church at the time of writing. One bound book, measuring 110mm x 185mm. Good condition. Page Title: "Hri Laka Inhumhim Dan i hria em; Hri a leng thin – natna chanchin leh inven dan leh enkawl dan. ""How to Protect Yourself from Infectious Diseases"" [undated]"
Description: Contains basic information on health relating to the title, “How to Protect Yourself from Infectious Diseases.” Seems to be a colonial-government-inspired publication, at least from the authorship. This book communicates in simple terms ideas about fighting diseases perceived as common to Lushai Hills. Measles, whooping cough, diphtheria, influenza, the mumps, chicken pox, dysentery, typhoid, cholera, and hook worm are discussed. Prevention, symptoms, and cures are given. Note that C.S. Zawna (late) has bound this book together with Chaw Tha I Hria Em? ( Do you Know Healthy Food?) (1941). The book must have been published c1941, or at least in the early 1940s. One bound book, measuring 131mm x 215mm. Cover ripped and binding home-made, but readable and otherwise good. Page Title: "First Aid I. Rrecorded in The New Indiskul Excercise Book, Saizawna, Student Teacher, First Aid, 3.2.1936 [1936]"
Description: Containing a record of contemporary first aid techniques, this is a very important source for the burgeoning field of medical history in Mizoram. Human biology is discussed, as are symptoms and remedies, ranging from bleeding to methods for treating fractures, and from the treatment of strokes to methods of patient aftercare. There is one loose page in the second workbook, but otherwise everything in reasonable condition.                                                          View images from this file (51)

Page Title: Record of the Rainfall of Serkawn Station from 1912 to 1946 [12 Jul 1940]
Description: A unique record, kept by C. S. Zawna over the year, which provides a glimpse into the region's environmental history and climate. Traditional Mizo periodization in history is sometimes related to the massive landslides such levels of precipitation occasionally cause. For instance, Mizo tradition often dates events from the minpui kum, of the “year of the great landslide.” This particular record book notes that between 1912 and 1940, some 3, 533 inches of rain fell in Serkawn. Were we, for a crude but telling experiment, to extrapolate this same rate of Serkawn rainfall up to the present 2011, we might reasonably expect some 12, 491 inches of rain to have fallen on Serkawn in the last 99 years. This record is thus remarkably well preserved, considering every inch of this rain fell in its vicinity It would take some 102 Christian Hospital Serkawn Buses stacked on top of one another to match the height of rainfall that this book has been subject to over the years. One book, measuring 173mm x 207mm. Good condition.                                                          View images from this file (116)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only

Page Title: paper records of C. S. Zawna [1938-1953]
Description: These records mostly focus on education, such as teacher training, examinations, student activities, and even school sports. Organizations featured include the Serkawn Boys School, Lunglei Boy Scouts, Serkawn Middle School, and Government records regarding the inspection of schools in South Lushai Hills, and Sikul Meichher (a newsletter of the Teachers Association in South Lushai Hills). One record includes information on teachers' wages which may be considered personal. Teachers Associations news are included, as well as curricula and sample examinations. A booklet for the 1944 Jubilee celebration of the Baptist Church in South Lushai Hills is also included. A small bundle of loose paper records. Ranges from excellent to decent, but text is all legible. The supplementary information concerns a wide variety of topics, from geographical information and local prices activities to the education, health, and penal policies of the British Raj in each district. One book, measuring 185mm x 275mm. Binding severely damaged; loose pages, but better than the DC Office's second copy of the same book. Page Title: "Sakawlh-Lal Manna Vanthar Bu . ""How to Destroy the Beast"" - Book 1 to Book 27 [c 1913]"
Description: The title of Tlira's work (Sakawlh-Lal Manna Vanthar Bu) roughly translates to “How to Destroy the Beast”, and is a lengthy exposee of Tlira's original religious vision, prophesy, and doctrine. This collection could offer researchers not only a glimpse into Tlira's own religious breakaway movement (which was the first 'indigenous' alternative to the British missionaries' efforts), but also into then contemporary culture, identity, worldview, authority, and everyday life. Tlira founded the region's first indigenous Christian church movement, which broke away from the fledgling but dominant British-missionary-led Church in 1913. Tlira's movement continues to have followers in today's Mizoram—they are labelled by others as 'Tlira Pawl' though do not seem to have any self-identification as such. Twenty seven bound exercise books, each measuring 250 mm by 168 mm. The actual text is well preserved, though the bindings on most of the exercise books are separating, with the occasional page broken free. Stains mark certain pages.                                                          View images from this file (1866)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only

Page Title: My Sermons [May 1921]
Description: Contains Rev. Liangkhaia's 1921 notes for a wide range of sermons delivered in Mizo Presbyterian churches. Rev. Liangkhaia (1884—1979), one of the early Christian Mizo pastors and historians, wrote nearly fifty books and hundreds of articles during his lifetime. His works on the origin and culture of the Mizos are seminal in today's Mizoram, a fact that owes a great deal to the efforts of his grandson, Prof. Laltluangliana, who has worked to publish many of Liangkhaia's early works. One bound, “Assam Girls School” exercise book, measuring 165mm x 204mm. Good condition. Page Title: Diary of Rev. Liangkhaia [1942]
Description: Rev. Liangkhaia's personal notations aside, this “Sen's Diary” contains interesting information in its printed forward including: contemporary, war-time advertisements; important dates in history (featuring events in the history of the British Empire and the British Raj in India); notes on various calendars; weight, currency, and measurement conversions; first aid and medical concerns; telegram fees; government, banking, postal, licensing, and financial information for within India; train fares within India; Calcutta street directory. A “War Supplement” (p. 81 – 3) contains interesting information on: concurrent WWII terms and WWII leaders globally. The second part of the Diary contains Rev. Liangkhaia's personal notes. Themes include: events in history; notes and tallies on WWII; and Rev. Liangkhaia's daily itineraries, including his many church activities, social responsibilities, and personal visits; [Khiangte_422]. One bound “Sen's Diary or Scribbling Journal (Est. 1885) for 1942”, re-bound in March 1988 by Prof. Laltluangliana Khiangte. Page Title: "Mizo Chanchin – Bu 1. Mizo History, Book 1 [1938]"
Description: This book is the first edition of the first book of history written by a Mizo author. It concerns the history, origin, language, identity, clan names, etc., of the Mizo tribe. Page Title: "Mizo Chanchin, Bu II – A History of Lushai Hills, Part II [1947]"
Description: This is the earliest history book written by indigenous scholar in Lushai Hills. The book is divided into two periods. The first concerns a theory of the origin of the Mizos, migration, genealogy, kinship, culture, myth, the origin of the chieftainship system, politics of chieftainship, and several biographies of important chiefs. Thirteen illustrations are given in black and white. The second part of the book begins with the British 'Lushai Expeditions', and moves on to examine British rule in Lushai Hills, local political administration, the introduction of Christianity and the history of the church in Lushai Hills, as well as giving biographies of several important British officers. This second volume of Mizo Chanchin was published by Rev. Liangkhaia nine years after the original. One bound book, measuring 135mm x217mm. Good condition.                                                          View images from this file (86)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only

Page Title: Chanchin Tha Marka Ziak. The Gospel of Mark [1905]
Description: This booklet contains a chapter-by-chapter Lushai commentary on and explanation of the Gospel According to Mark. This is one of the earliest available Gospels from Lushai Hills, although the handwritten date given on the final page (1905) is questionable. The British Library's Main Catalogue contains: Marka Evangel: St Mark's Gospel, in Lushai [Translated by E Rowlands] Madras : S.P.C.K. Press, 1906. It is thus unclear whether this chapter-by-chapter commentary on the Gospel was released before or after missionary E. Rowland's actual version of the Gospel itself. One bound booklet, measuring 165mm x 100mm. Generally good. Some small holes are evident in the pages towards the end of the booklet.                                                          View images from this file (48)

Page Title: "Serkawn Middle School Results, with effect from 1904. [1904-1952]"
Description: This record has always been held at the school compound, though the principal mentioned that is has occasionally been borrowed, and in fact allowed us to borrow the book for digitization. Contains examination results that date from the earliest exams administered in South Lushai Hills. Contains the results of primary examinations, South Lushai Hills, from 1904 to 1946. Contains the results of upper primary examinations, from 1905 to 1935, middle vernacular examinations from 1941 to 1950, and Middle English examinations, 1915 to 1952. 381 pages in total, excluding the cover page. Several important personalities appear in the work, including ex-Chief ministers, Brigadier T. Sailo, Lal Dena, and other prominent social activists, administrators, church leaders, government officials, etc. Note that we did not digitize all of the extended sections of blank pages. These blanks appear between the different result sections (primary, upper primary, middle vernacular, and middle English). The blank page numbers omitted from digitization were p. 120 to 238, p. 295 to 310, and p. 364 to 381. The Baptist Missionary Society ran the school originally until its name was changed to Zotlang Middle School, Serkawn. The school is now known locally as Serkawn Government Middle School. It seems that there are two other Xeroxed copies available in Mizoram state: one with Dr. C. L Hminga (Serkawn, Lunglei), one with C. Sangliana (Chanmari, Lunglei). One bound book, measuring 345mm x 220mm. Very good condition, except that the binding is detached in places.                                                          View images from this file (239)
Legal: Access is for research purposes only

Page Title: "Letters from Pu Dara to his wife, Pi Thangi [1913]"
Description: This collection of letters details Pu Dara's travels through Wales in 1913 to his wife, Pi Thangi, back in Aijal. Pu Dara's letters contain day-to-day reports about life in Wales, some personal reflections on salvation, and notes about his involvement in church-related activities in Wales. As one of the earliest Lushai men to travel abroad, his observations and activities are interesting. For instance, he makes comments on watching the cinema in Wales, and notes how the days seem longer there than home in Lushai Hills. Approximately thirty-two separate letters, each measuring 115mm x 175mm. Generally good. The single letter dated 14/1/1913 has been torn in two, with only the upper half surviving.                                                          View images from this file (108)

Page Title: Building Register [1899]
Description: This Building Register (1899) contains information on the construction and maintenance of buildings at Demagiri (also known contemporarily as Demgri, and today known as Tlabung), a then key station of British colonial administration situated along today's Mizoram and Bangladesh border. Contains maps, information on land and new building registrations, expenses of the Public Works Department, repair costs, etc. The final page had a loose 1981 map of the Demagiri Compound, which was digitized lastly, though included as a part of the same series. There was no electricity for EAP454's lights when this record was digitized, so sunlight was used. One bound record book, measuring 352mm x 220mm. Binding is separating in places, but otherwise generally good condition. Page Title: Inspection Register of Demagiri PS [1943-1971]
Description: This inspection record book of Demagiri contains official reports from various officers and locales. Many reports contain useful information about the strength of local police forces, the rates of crime in and around Demagiri, the internal workings of the colonial government in Lushai Hills, and the state of the local Chakma and Lushai habitants around Demagiri (today's Tlabung). There was no electricity for EAP454's lights when this record was digitized, so sunlight had to be used. One bound record book, measuring 215mm x 340mm. Some modern scribbles. Binding has loosened in places and certain entries have become greatly faded, but otherwise generally very good condition. Page Title: "Saihnuna, popularly known as Lenglal [1949]"
Description: Lenglal (or Saihnuna) was born in 1896, and converted to Christianity in 1921. He was appointed as chief (or 'lal') of Leng on July 5, 1927, by then Superintendent of Lushai Hills, N.E Parry. Lenglal was known for an able administrator and a composer of more than 100 songs. A collection of his songs book was compiled and published by his son Lalchuanga. He was the first circle No.VIII Red Cross President in the N. Vanlaiphai village Circle. In 1947, he was appointed as Advisory Council member in N Vanlaiphai Circle. This particular source book has extra handwritten notes added by Lenglal's son, Lalchuanga, between many pages. One bound book, measuring 340mm x 210mm... No cover. Initial pages very damaged. Otherwise good condition.                                                          View images from this file (68)

Page Title: Paper records of Khamliana Sailo Lal [1897-1944]
Description: This collection of the early paper records of the famous Lushai chief Khamliana Sailo (chief of Lungleng) contains several important documents. These include monetary receipts, invitations and correspondence from local British officials, awards, recommendations, a legal agreement, information on boundary disputes, and personal correspondence, The collection also includes what is reputed to be the first letter ever written by a Mizo. The letter, in Mizo, is written by Mizo lal (chief) Khamliana to Queen Victoria herself, in which he proudly informs her of his patriotic lighting of massive bonfires all round his village on her birthday (see EAP454_Sailo_99.TIF to EAP454_Sailo_102.TIF). A small collection of various paper records. Generally good condition.
